Front: Define: temerity (tuh-mer-i-tee)
Back: n. reckless confidence The temerity of the pirate crew cost them their ship. Root: temer (from Latin temere, meaning “rashly” or “recklessly”)

Front: Define: depredate (dep-rih-deyt)
Back: v. to plunder, pillage, destroy v. to exploit The Vikings depredated the whole valley. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning “down” or “away”), Root: pred (from Latin praedari, meaning “to plunder”)

Front: Define: genuflect (djen-yoo-flekt)
Back: v. to bend knee to ground (as in worship) v. to grovel The king's subjects genuflected when he entered the room. Root: genuflect (from Latin genu, meaning “knee” and flectere, meaning “to bend”)

Front: Define: wend (wend)
Back: v. to go, proceed, walk We wended our way through the market. Root: wend (from Old English wendan, meaning “to turn” or “to go”)

Front: Define: pelagic (puh-ladj-ik)
Back: adj. relating to open seas rather than waters adjacent to land The pelagic organism was only found in the deepest part of the ocean. Root: pelag (from Greek pelagos, meaning “sea”)

Front: Define: froward (froh-werd)
Back: adj. intractable, stubbornly disobedient, difficult to manage The froward mule sat down and refused to move all afternoon. Prefix: fro- (an old variant of “from”); Root: ward (indicating direction or tendency)

Front: Define: punctilious (puhngk-til-ee-uhs)
Back: adj. precise, paying attention to trivialities of etiquette A secretary who punctiliously records every detail. Root: punct (from Latin punctum, meaning “point”); Suffix: -ilious (indicating having the quality of)

Front: Define: aphorism (af-uh-riz-uhm)
Back: n. a tersely phrased truth or opinion; adage; epigram n. a brief statement of principle; or general truth The children had finally learned the meaning of the aphorism “You can't have your cake and eat it too”. Root: aphor (from Greek aphorizein, meaning “to define”); Suffix: -ism (indicating a practice or system)

Front: Define: purloin (per-loin, per-loin)
Back: v. to steal The manipulative thief purloined the diamonds after gaining the confidence of their location. Prefix: pur- (from Old French pur, meaning “for”); Root: loin (from Old French loigner, meaning “to remove”)

Front: Define: esoteric (es-uh-ter-ik)
Back: adj. intended for or understood only by a particular group adj. not publicly disclosed; confidential The esoteric ideas of the cult failed to enlighten many outsiders. Root: esoter (from Greek esoterikos, meaning “inner” or “within”)

Front: Define: succor (suhk-er)
Back: n. relief during a time of struggle The Red Cross provides succor to refugees in emergency shelters. Root: succor (from Latin succurrere, meaning “to run to help”)

Front: Define: protean (proh-tee-uhn)
Back: adj. readily assuming different forms or characters, versatile Fans regarded the protean actress as capable of playing any role. Root: Proteus (from Greek mythology, a sea god known for changing shape)

Front: Define: callous (kal-uhs)
Back: adj. insensitive; having no feeling The callous remark upset the entire family. Root: call (from Latin callum, meaning “hard skin”)

Front: Define: proscribe (proh-skrahyb)
Back: v. to prohibit or forbid as harmful or unlawful Citizens pushed to proscribe swimming in the polluted lake. Prefix: pro- (indicating forward or forth); Root: scribe (from Latin scribere, meaning “to write”)

Front: Define: denouement (dey-noo-mahn)
Back: n. an outcome or solution to a complex series of events Though public interest slackened after the arsonist was caught, the denouement of the case was just as interesting as the manhunt that had preceded it. Root: noue (from Latin nodare, meaning “to knot”); Prefix: de- (indicating removal or reversal)

Front: Define: supercilious (soo-per-sill-ee-uhs)
Back: adj. arrogant, overbearing; displaying condescending superiority over someone else His supercilious behavior drove away many of his peers. Prefix: super- (meaning “above” or “over”); Root: cili (from Latin cilium, meaning “eyelid”)

Front: Define: parley (pahr-lee)
Back: n. discussion between enemies, often to prepare terms of surrender The longtime enemies held a parley to work on peace negotiations. Root: parler (from French, meaning “to speak”)

Front: Define: apoplectic (ap-uh-plek-tik)
Back: adj. furious; enraged; overcome with anger When Jim found out he was fired, he apoplectically stormed out of the office. Root: apoplex (from Greek apoplexia, meaning “a seizure”); Suffix: -tic (indicating pertaining to)

Front: Define: simper (sim-per)
Back: v. to say with a coy smile; to smirk Dave simpered a feeble attempt at an apology. Root: simper (from Middle English simperen, meaning “to smile”)

Front: Define: miscegenation (mih-sedj-uh-ney-shuhn)
Back: n. the interbreeding of different races n. any mixture or hybrid Miscegenation, the intermarriage or mixing of different racial groups, was historically met with social and legal barriers in many societies. But today, miscegenation is widely accepted in many societies, and interracial relationships are common and often celebrated as a sign of cultural diversity and tolerance. Prefix: misc- (from Latin miscere, meaning “to mix”); Root: gen (from Latin genus, meaning “race” or “kind”); Suffix: -ation (indicating an action or process)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. recklessness Hint: starts with “t”
Back: temerity synonyms: arrogance, brashness, foolhardiness, audacity, impudence His temerity in challenging the seasoned lawyer surprised everyone in the courtroom.

Front: Fill in the blank: The invaders ________ the village, leaving little behind. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “to plunder or destroy”.
Back: depredated depredate (dep-rih-deyt) v. to plunder, pillage, destroy v. to exploit

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to bend knee to ground (as in worship) v. to grovel Hint: starts with “g”
Back: genuflect synonyms: kneel, beg, bow, prostrate, submit The faithful genuflect before the altar during the ceremony. He would rather leave the company than genuflect to the unreasonable demands of his boss.

Front: Fill in the blank: After the meeting, she ________ her way through the crowded streets back home. Hint: Starts with “w” and means “to go or proceed”.
Back: wended wend (wend) v. to go, proceed, walk

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. relating to open seas rather than waters adjacent to land Hint: starts with “p”
Back: pelagic synonyms: aquatic, oceanic, marine, deep-sea, oceanic The pelagic fish are adapted to life far from the shores, swimming in the deep ocean.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ child refused to listen to any instructions from his teacher. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “stubbornly disobedient”.
Back: froward froward (froh-werd) adj. intractable, stubbornly disobedient, difficult to manage

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. precise, paying attention to trivialities of etiquette Hint: starts with “p”
Back: punctilious synonyms: meticulous, careful, finicky, scrupulous, exacting, detailed She was punctilious about every detail of the formal dinner, ensuring everything was perfect.

Front: Fill in the blank: His speech was filled with insightful ________ that resonated with the audience. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “tersely phrased truths”.
Back: aphorisms aphorism (af-uh-riz-uhm) n. a tersely phrased truth or opinion; adage; epigram n. a brief statement of principle; or general truth

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to steal Hint: starts with “p”
Back: purloin synonyms: burglarize, cheat, swindle, filch, pilfer, take The thief managed to purloin several valuable paintings from the gallery.

Front: Fill in the blank: The professor's ________ lecture was difficult for those unfamiliar with the subject. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “intended for a particular group”.
Back: esoteric esoteric (es-uh-ter-ik) adj. intended for or understood only by a particular group adj. not publicly disclosed; confidential

Front: Name the vocab term: n. relief during a time of struggle Hint: starts with “s”
Back: succor synonyms: aid, comfort, refuge, support, assistance, help The refugees sought succor in neighboring countries after fleeing the conflict.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ talent allowed him to excel in both acting and directing. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “able to change easily”.
Back: protean protean (proh-tee-uhn) adj. readily assuming different forms or characters, versatile

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. insensitive; having no feeling Hint: starts with “c”
Back: callous synonyms: soulless, cruel, heartless, unfeeling, unsympathetic Her callous remarks about the disaster shocked everyone.

Front: Fill in the blank: The government decided to ________ the use of certain chemicals due to their harmful effects. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “to forbid or condemn”.
Back: proscribe proscribe (proh-skrahyb) v. to prohibit or forbid as harmful or unlawful

Front: Name the vocab term: n. an outcome or solution to a complex series of events Hint: starts with “d”
Back: denouement synonyms: finale, final achievement, resolution, conclusion, outcome The denouement of the mystery novel tied together all the loose ends.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ attitude made her unpopular among her colleagues. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “arrogantly disdainful”.
Back: supercilious supercilious (soo-per-sill-ee-uhs) adj. arrogant, overbearing; displaying condescending superiority over someone else

Front: Name the vocab term: n. discussion between enemies, often to prepare terms of surrender Hint: starts with “p”
Back: parley synonyms: conference, mediation, negotiation, dialogue, discussion The generals held a parley to negotiate the terms of the ceasefire.

Front: Fill in the blank: He became ________ when he discovered the mistake in the report. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “overcome with extreme anger”.
Back: apoplectic apoplectic (ap-uh-plek-tik) adj. furious; enraged; overcome with anger adj. relating to a stroke

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to say with a coy smile; to smirk Hint: starts with “s”
Back: simper synonyms: grin, leer, sneer, smirk, smirk, smile coyly She simpered at the compliment, clearly enjoying the attention.

Front: Fill in the blank: The laws against ________ were finally repealed in the 20th century. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “interbreeding of different racial groups”.
Back: miscegenation miscegenation (mih-sedj-uh-ney-shuhn) n. the interbreeding of different races n. any mixture or hybrid

Front: Define: androgynous (an-drodj-uh-nuhs)
Back: adj. not distinguishable between male and female The name Sam is androgynous because it could stand for Samantha or Samuel. Prefix: andro- (from Greek anēr, meaning “man”); Suffix: -gynous (from Greek gynē, meaning “woman”)

Front: Define: covey (kuhv-ee)
Back: n. a family of partridges n. a small group Outside the classroom was a covey of giggling schoolgirls. Root: cov- (from Middle English covee, meaning “brood of birds”)

Front: Define: supine (adj. soo-pahyn)
Back: adj. inactive, lying on one's back apathetically adj. morally slack The officials exhibited a supine acceptance of corruption. Root: supin- (from Latin supinus, meaning “lying on the back”)

Front: Define: cozen (kuhz-uhn)
Back: v. to cheat, beguile, or deceive The corrupt televangelist cozened money from viewers by lying about charitable intentions. Root: coz- (from Italian cozzonare, meaning “to cheat”)

Front: Define: limpid (lim-pid)
Back: adj. calm, untroubled, serene adj. transparent, clear (as of water, air, or crystal) The family flew a kite down by the limpid blue pond. Root: limp- (from Latin limpidus, meaning “clear”)

Front: Define: refulgent (rih-fuhl-juhnt)
Back: adj. shining radiantly; brilliant The refulgent palace seemed out of place amid the poverty of the villages surrounding it. Prefix: re- (from Latin, meaning “again” or “back”); Root: fulg- (from Latin fulgere, meaning “to shine”)

Front: Define: phlegmatic (fleg-mat-ik)
Back: adj. hard to excite, calm, sluggish adj. unemotional, stoic Pete's phlegmatic response was difficult for his friends to read. Root: phlegm- (from Greek phlegma, meaning “inflammation” or “phlegm”)

Front: Define: attenuate (uh-ten-yoo-eyt)
Back: v. to weaken or reduce in force or value v. to make small or fine The medicine attenuated the fever's effect. Prefix: at- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: tenu- (from Latin tenuis, meaning “thin”)

Front: Define: disingenuous (diss-in-djen-yoo-uhs)
Back: adj. lacking in sincerity or candor When the oil prospector's promises were discovered to be disingenuous, he was run out of town. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “not”); Root: ingenu- (from Latin ingenuus, meaning “natural” or “honest”)

Front: Define: epistle (uh-piss-uhl)
Back: n. a written message, usually a formal letter The epistle was hand-delivered by a confidant in order to avoid interception. Root: epist- (from Greek epistole, meaning “letter”)

Front: Define: factitious (fak-tish-uhs)
Back: adj. produced artificially; not natural adj. fake The factitious laughter of insincere talk show hosts makes my skin crawl. Root: fact- (from Latin facere, meaning “to make”); Suffix: -itious (indicating a tendency or quality)

Front: Define: pied (pahyd)
Back: adj. containing patches of two or more colors, usually in blotches The jester's pied coat was stitched together from scraps of blue and red fabric. Root: pie- (from Middle English pied, meaning “having patches of two or more colors”)

Front: Define: militate (mill-ih-teyt)
Back: v. to have strong influence or effect; to operate against or sometimes in favor of something. The volatility of the situation militated against any rash action. Where have the universities been militating for lower tax rates at the top? Root: milit- (from Latin militare, meaning “to serve as a soldier”)

Front: Define: Stygian (stidj-ee-uhn)
Back: adj. dark, gloomy, dismal adj. infernal, hellish The stygian murk of the cave made it difficult to navigate. Root: Styg- (from Greek Styx, meaning “the river Styx”)

Front: Define: gainsay (geyn-sey)
Back: v. to declare false v. to deny v. to contradict or claim exception to Evidence and witness testimony all gainsaid the defendant's claims. Prefix: gain- (from Old English gean-, meaning “against”); Root: say (from Old English secgan, meaning “to say”)

Front: Define: palliate (pal-ee-eyt)
Back: v. to make something appear less serious; to mitigate; to alleviate The student tried to palliate the significance of his plagiarism. Root: palli- (from Latin palliare, meaning “to cloak”); Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: nostrum (nos-truhm)
Back: n. cure-all, questionable remedy, or a placebo An ad on television depicted a nostrum that claims to cure hangovers. Root: nostr- (from Latin nostrum, meaning “our” or “our own”)

Front: Define: obstreperous (uhb-strep-er-uhs)
Back: adj. unruly, noisy, loudly stubborn The obstreperous two-year-old cried the entire train ride. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: streper- (from Latin strepere, meaning “to make a noise”)

Front: Define: precocious (prih-koh-shuhs)
Back: adj. unusually quick development or maturation, especially in intelligence The child's precocious understanding of calculus stunned his teachers. Prefix: pre- (from Latin, meaning “before”); Root: coc- (from Latin coquere, meaning “to cook” or “to ripen”)

Front: Define: regale (rih-geyl)
Back: v. to entertain; to supply lavishly n. a choice piece especially of food Steve regaled his guests with exciting tales. Root: regal- (from Old French regaler, meaning “to entertain or feast”)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. hermaphroditic adj. not distinguishable between male and female Hint: starts with “a”
Back: androgynous synonyms: cross-sexual, unisexual, trans-sexual, gender-neutral, ambiguous The creature in the myth was portrayed as androgynous, embodying both male and female traits. The androgynous fashion trend blurred traditional gender lines in clothing.

Front: Fill in the blank: We spotted a ________ of partridges in the field during our hike. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “a small flock or group”.
Back: covey covey (kuhv-ee) n. a family of partridges n. a small group

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. inactive, lying on one's back apathetically adj. morally slack Hint: starts with “s”
Back: supine synonyms: lying down, flat; apathetic, lazy, prostrate, recumbent He lay supine on the couch, unwilling to do anything productive. The government's supine attitude towards corruption allowed it to flourish.

Front: Fill in the blank: The con artist ________ people into giving him their life savings. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “to deceive or trick”.
Back: cozened cozen (kuhz-uhn) v. to cheat, beguile, or deceive

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. calm, untroubled, serene adj. transparent, clear (as of water, air, or crystal) Hint: starts with “l”
Back: limpid synonyms: tranquil, peaceful; glassy, translucent, clear, unclouded, bright The limpid expression on her face showed she wasn't worried at all. The limpid water of the lake made it easy to see the fish swimming below.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ glow of the setting sun bathed the landscape in golden light. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “shining brightly”.
Back: refulgent refulgent (rih-fuhl-juhnt) adj. shining radiantly; brilliant

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. hard to excite, calm, sluggish adj. unemotional, stoic Hint: starts with “p”
Back: phlegmatic synonyms: apathetic, dispassionate, lethargic, unemotional, placid, indifferent His phlegmatic response to the exciting news surprised everyone. The phlegmatic soldier remained composed even in the face of danger.

Front: Fill in the blank: The long drought ________ the strength of the river's current. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “weakened or reduced”.
Back: attenuated attenuate (uh-ten-yoo-eyt) v. to weaken or reduce in force or value v. to make small or fine

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. lacking in sincerity or candor Hint: starts with “d”
Back: disingenuous synonyms: dishonest, crooked, deceitful, duplicitous, insincere His disingenuous apology did little to mend the rift between them.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scholar wrote an ________ to his colleagues, detailing his latest findings. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “a formal letter”.
Back: epistle epistle (uh-piss-uhl) n. a written message, usually a formal letter

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. produced artificially; not natural adj. fake Hint: starts with “f”
Back: factitious synonyms: artificial, false, sham, manufactured, synthetic, spurious The diamonds in the necklace were factitious but still looked stunning. His factitious enthusiasm at the event was apparent to everyone.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ horse stood out with its distinct black and white markings. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “having patches of different colors”.
Back: pied pied (pahyd) adj. containing patches of two or more colors, usually in blotches

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to have substantial weight or bearing on; usually to argue against something or make it less likely. Hint: starts with “m”
Back: militate synonyms: weigh, important, influential, affect, contribute, determine The evidence presented in the trial will militate heavily against the defendant.

Front: Fill in the blank: The forest at night had a ________ atmosphere, making it feel eerie and foreboding. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “dark, gloomy, or hellish”.
Back: stygian Stygian (stidj-ee-uhn) adj. dark, gloomy, dismal adj. infernal, hellish

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to declare false v. to deny v. to contradict or claim exception to Hint: starts with “g”
Back: gainsay synonyms: deny, disaffirm, disprove, contradict, refute, challenge No one could gainsay the facts presented in the report. It was difficult to gainsay her argument given the strong data backing it up.

Front: Fill in the blank: The doctor prescribed medication to ________ the symptoms of the disease. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “to ease without curing”.
Back: palliate palliate (pal-ee-eyt) v. to make something appear less serious; to mitigate; to alleviate

Front: Name the vocab term: n. cure-all, questionable remedy, or a placebo Hint: starts with “n”
Back: nostrum synonyms: elixir, quick fix, aid, remedy, potion, fix The herbalist claimed to have a nostrum for every ailment, but none of them worked.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ crowd refused to leave, even after the event was over. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “noisily defiant or unruly”.
Back: obstreperous obstreperous (uhb-strep-er-uhs) adj. unruly, noisy, loudly stubborn

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unusually quick development or maturation, especially in intelligence Hint: starts with “p”
Back: precocious synonyms: advanced, developed, quick, intelligent, mature, ahead of one's years, gifted The precocious child was reading at a college level by the age of 10.

Front: Fill in the blank: He ________ the guests with stories of his adventures abroad. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “entertained or delighted”.
Back: regaled regale (rih-geyl) v. to entertain; to feast

Front: Define: ambit (am-bit)
Back: n. the extent, boundary or scope of something Though I find her actions reprehensible, she was acting within the ambit of the law and so my hands are tied. Root: ambi (from Latin ambitus, meaning “going around”)

Front: Define: apostate (uh-poss-teyt)
Back: n. one who abandons a belief, cause, party or religion The apostate is dealt with very harshly in many religious traditions. Prefix: apo- (from Greek, meaning “away from”)

Front: Define: sophistry (sof-uh-stree)
Back: n. fallacious reasoning; faulty, although plausible, logic The students were quickly convinced by the professor's sophistry and did not inquire further. Root: soph (from Greek sophos, meaning “wise”)

Front: Define: perspicuity (purr-spih-kyoo-ih-tee)
Back: n. clarity or perceptiveness in speech, thought, or writing The perspicuity of the writing made a complicated topic easy for all to understand. Root: spec (from Latin specere, meaning “to look”)

Front: Define: enjoin (en-join)
Back: v. to command or direct an action with authority v. to prohibit or forbid an action The captain enjoined his men to respect the local laws while on shore leave. Prefix: en- (from Latin, meaning “in” or “on”)

Front: Define: fulsome (fool-suhm)
Back: adj. offensively flattering or insincere. adj. offensive to the taste adj. generous or abundant I prefer Sara's sincere criticism to all the fulsome praise I receive from Deb. Suffix: -some (from Old English, meaning “characterized by”)

Front: Define: imprecation (im-prih-key-shuhn)
Back: n. a curse The witch cast an imprecation on the villagers. Prefix: im- (from Latin, meaning “in” or “upon”), Root: prec (from Latin precari, meaning “to pray”)

Front: Define: extenuate (ik-sten-yoo-eyt)
Back: v. to lessen the magnitude or seriousness of; to mitigate The prisoner's illness may extenuate the conditions of his captivity, but it shall not lead me to order his early release. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out”), Root: tenu (from Latin tenuis, meaning “thin”)

Front: Define: ineluctable (in-ih-luhk-tuh-buhl)
Back: adj. certain, inevitable, unavoidable A hectic lifestyle seems to be the ineluctable product of modernity. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “not”), Root: eluct (from Latin eluctari, meaning “to struggle out”)

Front: Define: vitiate (vish-ee-eyt)
Back: v. to reduce the quality of v. to corrupt The tear in the painting vitiated its overall appeal and halved its appraisal cost. Root: vit (from Latin vitium, meaning “fault” or “defect”)

Front: Define: turpitude (tur-pih-tood)
Back: n. depravity, baseness n. a vile or wicked act Because of stealing, he was dismissed on grounds of moral turpitude. Root: turp (from Latin turpis, meaning “shameful”)

Front: Define: plaintive (pleyn-tiv)
Back: adj. mournful, sorrowful, melancholy The procession was led by the plaintive strains of the bagpipe. Root: plaint (from Latin plangere, meaning “to lament”)

Front: Define: pertinacious (purt-n-ey-shuhs)
Back: adj. holding tenaciously to a belief adj. stubbornly unyielding Her pertinacious devotion to the debunked theory led her to be marginalized in the scientific community. Prefix: per- (from Latin, meaning “thoroughly”), Root: ten (from Latin tenere, meaning “to hold”)

Front: Define: recreant (rek-ree-uhnt)
Back: adj. unfaithful, disloyal to belief or principle adj. cowardly or craven n. one who is a coward, unfaithful, or disloyal The recreant knight ran from the battle. Prefix: re- (from Latin, meaning “again” or “back”), Root: cred (from Latin credere, meaning “to believe”)

Front: Define: adduce (uh-doos)
Back: v. to offer as proof in an argument Seth adduced several recent studies in support of his hypothesis. Prefix: ad- (from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: duc (from Latin ducere, meaning “to lead”)

Front: Define: traduce (truh-doos)
Back: v. to slander or speak maliciously of As a “green energy” campaigner, I distrust politicians who habitually traduce the motivations of environmentalists. Prefix: tra- (variant of trans-, from Latin, meaning “across”), Root: duc (from Latin ducere, meaning “to lead”)

Front: Define: apposite (app-uh-zit)
Back: adj. relevant, suitable, or fitting Though clever, Dmitry's pun was not apposite to the solemn occasion. Prefix: ap- (variant of ad-, from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: posit (from Latin ponere, meaning “to place”)

Front: Define: discursive (diss-kurr-siv)
Back: adj. rambling aimlessly through a wide range of subjects. The poor speaker gave a rambling, discursive speech. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart”), Root: cur (from Latin currere, meaning “to run”)

Front: Define: avocation (av-uh-key-shuhn)
Back: n. an extracurricular activity; a hobby My favorite avocation is playing baseball in the summertime. Prefix: a- (variant of ab-, from Latin, meaning “away from”), Root: voc (from Latin vocare, meaning “to call”)

Front: Define: adumbrate (uh-duhm-breyt)
Back: v. to foreshadow vaguely v. to produce a faint outline or resemblance of something The first volume merely adumbrates the basics of the story to be developed in the next two books. Prefix: ad- (from Latin, meaning “to”), Root: umbr (from Latin umbra, meaning “shadow”)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the extent, boundary or scope of something Hint: starts with “a”
Back: ambit synonyms: compass, extension, range, scope, reach, limits The discussion remained within the ambit of the assigned topics for the meeting.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ was shunned by his former comrades after leaving the movement. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “one who abandons their faith or cause”.
Back: apostate apostate (uh-poss-teyt) n. one who abandons a belief, cause, party or religion

Front: Name the vocab term: n. fallacious reasoning; faulty, although plausible, logic Hint: starts with “s”
Back: sophistry synonyms: fallacy, inconsistency, misleading argument, specious reasoning The politician's argument was nothing more than sophistry, designed to mislead the public.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ of her speech made even the most complex ideas easy to understand. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “clarity in expression”.
Back: perspicuity perspicuity (purr-spih-kyoo-ih-tee) n. clarity or perceptiveness in speech, thought, or writing

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to command or direct an action with authority v. to prohibit or forbid an action Hint: starts with “e”
Back: enjoin synonyms: order, command; disallow, outlaw, dictate, direct, mandate The court enjoined the company to halt its illegal practices immediately. The rules enjoin students from bringing their phones to class.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ praise made everyone uncomfortable, as it felt exaggerated and fake. Hint: Starts with “f” and means “excessively flattering or abundant”.
Back: fulsome fulsome (fool-suhm) adj. offensively flattering or insincere. adj. offensive to the taste

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a curse Hint: starts with “i”
Back: imprecation synonyms: spell, hex, malediction, anathema, curse The angry witch muttered an imprecation under her breath as she walked away.

Front: Fill in the blank: The lawyer tried to ________ the defendant's actions by highlighting his difficult upbringing. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to lessen the seriousness of”.
Back: extenuate extenuate (ik-sten-yoo-eyt) v. to lessen the magnitude or seriousness of; to mitigate

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. certain, inevitable, unavoidable Hint: starts with “i”
Back: ineluctable synonyms: inescapable, destined, inevitable, unavoidable, certain The ineluctable passage of time affects everyone, no matter their status.

Front: Fill in the blank: His repeated lies ________ the credibility of his testimony. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “spoiled or corrupted”.
Back: vitiated vitiate (vish-ee-eyt) v. to reduce the quality of v. to corrupt

Front: Name the vocab term: n. depravity, baseness n. a vile act Hint: starts with “t”
Back: turpitude synonyms: depravity, baseness, wickedness, immorality, corruption The turpitude of the criminal's actions shocked the entire community. His turpitude was evident when he betrayed his own family for money.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ melody of the violin expressed a deep sense of loss. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “expressing sorrow”.
Back: plaintive plaintive (pleyn-tiv) adj. mournful, sorrowful, melancholy

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. holding tenaciously to a belief adj. stubbornly unyielding Hint: starts with “p”
Back: pertinacious synonyms: stubbornly unyielding, tenacious, persistent, dogged, resolute The pertinacious activist refused to back down, despite the opposition. His pertinacious nature made it difficult to convince him to change his mind.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ knight abandoned his comrades in their hour of need. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “cowardly or unfaithful”.
Back: recreant recreant (rek-ree-uhnt) adj. unfaithful, disloyal to belief or principle adj. cowardly or craven n. one who is a coward, unfaithful, or disloyal

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to offer as proof in an argument Hint: starts with “a”
Back: adduce synonyms: introduce, exhibit, cite, bring forward, present, mention The lawyer adduced several pieces of evidence to support her client's innocence.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was quick to ________ his rivals, spreading false rumors to damage their reputations. Hint: Starts with “t” and means “to speak maliciously or slander”.
Back: traduce traduce (truh-doos) v. to slander or speak maliciously of

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. relevant, suitable, or fitting Hint: starts with “a”
Back: apposite synonyms: pertinent, timely, appropriate, fitting, applicable, relevant His apposite remarks during the meeting helped to clarify the situation.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ lecture covered topics ranging from philosophy to pop culture. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “rambling or wandering in speech”.
Back: discursive discursive (diss-kurr-siv) adj. rambling aimlessly through a wide range of subjects adj. drawing conclusions based on reason (as opposed to intuition)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. an extracurricular activity; a hobby Hint: starts with “a”
Back: avocation synonyms: hobby, recreation, pastime, interest, pursuit, diversion Her avocation of painting provided a creative outlet outside of her day job.

Front: Fill in the blank: The author ________ the tragic ending early in the novel. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “to foreshadow or outline”.
Back: adumbrated adumbrate (uh-duhm-breyt) v. to foreshadow vaguely v. to produce a faint outline or resemblance of something

Front: Define: alchemy (al-kuh-me)
Back: n. the medieval study of transforming lead into gold Although it was never proven possible, alchemy is in many ways related to the chemistry we study today. Prefix: al- (from Arabic, meaning “the”); Root: chem (from Greek khemia, meaning “art of transmuting metals”)

Front: Define: allege (uh-ledge)
Back: v. to state that something is true without providing proof The neighbors alleged that it was the store owner who started the fire, but it turned out that he had been out of town after speaking with him. Prefix: al- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: leg (from Latin legare, meaning “to send” or “to bring”)

Front: Define: allude (uh-lewd)
Back: v. to refer to another concept indirectly She would occasionally allude to a summer house, though nobody knew exactly where it was. Prefix: al- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: lud (from Latin ludere, meaning “to play”)

Front: Define: altruism (al-true-iz-um)
Back: n. selfless concern for others Many charities were formed thanks to Rajiv's altruism and generosity. Root: altr (from Latin alter, meaning “other”)

Front: Define: ambivalence (am-biv-uh-lunce)
Back: n. confused or contradicting feelings The bride's ambivalence towards the color of the roses meant the groom had to decide. Prefix: ambi- (from Latin, meaning “both”); Root: val (from Latin valere, meaning “to be strong”)

Front: Define: amble (am-bul)
Back: v. to walk slowly The old man ambled over to our table and started up a conversation. Root: ambul (from Latin ambulare, meaning “to walk”)

Front: Define: ameliorate (uh-meal-yuh-rate)
Back: v. to make better The new medicine ameliorated her condition rather quickly. Prefix: a- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: melior (from Latin, meaning “better”)

Front: Define: amenable (uh-men-ih-bull)
Back: adj. open to suggestion or criticism adj. accountable A good manager is amenable to his employee's new ideas. Prefix: a- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: men (from Latin minari, meaning “to threaten”)

Front: Define: analgesic (ann-ul-djee-zick)
Back: n. pain reliever After the surgery, the doctor prescribed an analgesic for her patient's leg. Prefix: an- (from Greek, meaning “without”); Root: alg (from Greek algos, meaning “pain”)

Front: Define: anecdote (ann-ik-dote)
Back: n. a story of a specific incident, used as an example or for entertainment The actor's acceptance speech included an anecdote about his first audition. Prefix: an- (from Greek, meaning “not”); Root: ecdote (from Greek ekdotos, meaning “published”)

Front: Define: annul (uh-null)
Back: v. to declare invalid The couple had their marriage annulled when it was revealed that the groom was still married to another woman. Prefix: an- (from Latin ad-, meaning “to”); Root: nul (from Latin nullus, meaning “none”)

Front: Define: didactic (die-dak-tick)
Back: adj. overly instructive, educational He may mean well, but Pat's efforts to help came across as fussy and didactic. Root: didact (from Greek didaktikos, meaning “apt at teaching”)

Front: Define: diffident (diff-ih-dunt)
Back: adj. lacking confidence; restrained or reserved Since it was her first day, Lucy ventured only diffident answers to her superiors' requests for input. Prefix: dif- (from Latin dis-, meaning “apart”); Root: fid (from Latin fidere, meaning “to trust”)

Front: Define: diffuse (v. dih-fewz; adj. dih-fewss)
Back: v. to spread out adj. widely spread, scattered adj. wordy and rambling Such a diffuse network of law enforcement will not be able to eliminate all instances of crime. Prefix: dif- (from Latin dis-, meaning “apart”); Root: fus (from Latin fundere, meaning “to pour”)

Front: Define: dilapidated (dih-lap-ih-date-id)
Back: adj. ruined, worn down The abandoned house was dilapidated from years of neglect. Prefix: di- (from Latin dis-, meaning “apart”); Root: lapid (from Latin lapis, meaning “stone”)

Front: Define: dilate (die-late)
Back: v. to widen or enlarge v. to give a long speech on a subject The eye drops dilated his pupils so the eye doctor could better examine them. Prefix: di- (from Latin dis-, meaning “apart”); Root: lat (from Latin latus, meaning “wide”)

Front: Define: dilettante (dill-ih-tont)
Back: n. a person with an interest in a topic without really commiting n. a patron of the arts The dance school accepted dilettantes as well as trained professionals. Root: dilett (from Italian dilettare, meaning “to delight”)

Front: Define: dirge (durge)
Back: n. a mournful song We heard a chorus singing a dirge as the funeral procession began. Root: dirg (from Latin dirigere, meaning “to direct”)

Front: Define: disabuse (diss-uh-bewz)
Back: v. to free from a misconception or error in thought Luke made it his goal to disabuse his students of the notion that they didn't need to work hard to do well. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart”); Root: abuse (from Latin abuti, meaning “to misuse”)

Front: Define: disaffect (diss-uh-fect)
Back: v. to make someone lose loyalty or affection Her attention-seeking behavior disaffected many of her classmates. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart”); Root: affect (from Latin affectus, meaning “emotion”)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the medieval study of transforming lead into gold Hint: starts with “a”
Back: alchemy synonyms: sorcery, wizardry, medieval science, magical transformation, mysticism, theurgy Medieval scientists pursued alchemy, hoping to turn base metals into gold.

Front: Fill in the blank: He ________ that the company was involved in illegal activities, but no evidence was presented. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “claimed without proof”.
Back: alleged allege (uh-ledge) v. to state that something is true without providing proof

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to refer to another concept indirectly Hint: starts with “a”
Back: allude synonyms: bring up, imply, mention, hint at, suggest, insinuate The author alluded to a famous historical event in the opening chapter of the novel.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her decision to volunteer at the shelter was an act of pure ________. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “selfless concern for others”.
Back: altruism altruism (al-true-iz-um) n. selfless concern for others

Front: Name the vocab term: n. confused or contradicting feelings Hint: starts with “a”
Back: ambivalence synonyms: confusion, dilemma, hesitation, uncertainty, mixed feelings, conflict His ambivalence about moving to a new city made the decision difficult.

Front: Fill in the blank: They ________ along the park path, enjoying the sunny afternoon. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “walked slowly and leisurely”.
Back: ambled amble (am-bul) v. to walk slowly

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make better Hint: starts with “a”
Back: ameliorate synonyms: amend, help, improve, enhance, alleviate The government launched several initiatives to ameliorate living conditions in the city.

Front: Fill in the blank: She was ________ to feedback and worked hard to improve her skills. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “open to suggestion or cooperation”.
Back: amenable amenable (uh-men-ih-bull) adj. open to suggestion or criticism adj. accountable

Front: Name the vocab term: n. pain reliever Hint: starts with “a”
Back: analgesic synonyms: painkiller, soother, anodyne, remedy, analgesic agent The doctor prescribed an analgesic to help manage the patient's pain after surgery.

Front: Fill in the blank: He shared a humorous ________ about his childhood during the family gathering. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “a short, amusing or interesting story”.
Back: anecdote anecdote (ann-ik-dote) n. a story of a specific incident, used as an example or for entertainment

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to declare invalid Hint: starts with “a”
Back: annul synonyms: void, abolish, cancel, invalidate, nullify, revoke The court decided to annul the contract due to a breach of terms.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ tone made it difficult for the students to engage with the lesson. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “intended to teach”.
Back: didactic didactic (die-dak-tick) adj. overly instructive or preachy

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. lacking confidence; restrained or reserved Hint: starts with “d”
Back: diffident synonyms: hesitant, unconfident, shy, timid, self-doubting Her diffident manner made her seem shy during the presentation, though her ideas were strong.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scent of flowers ________ through the air as we entered the garden. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “spread out or scattered”.
Back: diffused diffuse (v. dih-fewz; adj. dih-fewss) v. to spread out adj. widely spread, scattered adj. wordy and rambling

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. ruined, worn down Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dilapidated synonyms: ramshackle, wasted, decayed, crumbling, deteriorated, neglected The dilapidated house on the corner had been abandoned for years.

Front: Fill in the blank: The doctor used eye drops to ________ his pupils for the examination. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “to expand or speak at length”.
Back: dilate dilate (die-late) v. to widen or enlarge v. to give a long speech on a subject

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a person with an interest in a topic without really committing n. a patron of the arts Hint: starts with “d”
Back: dilettante synonyms: green, unskilled; artist, connoisseur, amateur, enthusiast, hobbyist As a dilettante, he dabbled in painting but never took it seriously.

Front: Fill in the blank: The choir sang a somber ________ at the funeral. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “a funeral song”.
Back: dirge dirge (durge) n. a mournful song

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to free from a misconception or error in thought Hint: starts with “d”
Back: disabuse synonyms: correct, debunk, enlighten, clarify, set straight He worked hard to disabuse his friend of the belief in a common conspiracy theory.

Front: Fill in the blank: The manager's harsh treatment of employees began to ________ many from the company. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “to alienate the affection of”.
Back: disaffect disaffect (diss-uh-fect) v. to make someone lose loyalty or affection

Front: Define: discern (dih-surn)
Back: v. to recognize, to recognize as different From a distance, it was difficult for Josh to discern who was waving at him. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “asunder”); Root: cern (from Latin cernere, meaning “to separate” or “to distinguish”)

Front: Define: discomfit (diss-kum-fit)
Back: v. to unsettle v. to upset or prevent from succeeding The presence of the victim's family at the trial discomfited the accused. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “asunder”); Root: comfit (from Latin confīcere, meaning “to make” or “to prepare”)

Front: Define: hackneyed (hack-need)
Back: adj. overdone or cliché The student's poem contained the hackneyed expressions that typically fill teenage diaries. Root: hackney (from Middle English, meaning “to use a horse for ordinary riding”), Suffix: -ed (used to form the past participle of regular verbs)

Front: Define: hallmark (hall-mark)
Back: n. a unique, identifying trait n. a mark used to indicate the purity of certain metals Complete obedience is the hallmark of a good soldier. Root: hall (from Old English heall, meaning “large room” or “hall”); Root: mark (from Old English mearc, meaning “boundary” or “sign”)

Front: Define: harangue (huh-rang)
Back: v. to speak with intense emotions n. a rant The lobbyists arrived at the senator's office expecting to make a deal, but instead they received a 45-minute harangue from the angry politician. Root: harangue (from Old Italian aringare, meaning “to speak in public”)

Front: Define: hedonism (heed-in-iz-um)
Back: n. dedication to pursuing pleasure Jake's hedonism became apparent when he quit his job rather than cancel his trip to the Bahamas. Root: hedon (from Greek hēdonē, meaning “pleasure”); Suffix: -ism (from Greek -ismos, indicating a practice or belief)

Front: Define: tan (tan)
Back: v. to whip v. to make leather out of animal hide He spent days tanning the leather properly. Root: tan (from Old English tannian, meaning “to convert hide into leather”)

Front: Define: heretical (huh-ret-ih-kull)
Back: adj. differing from official beliefs Galileo's discoveries of the nature of Earth's place in the universe were considered heretical at the time. Root: heretic (from Greek hairetikos, meaning “able to choose”); Suffix: -al (forming adjectives, meaning “relating to”)

Front: Define: hieroglyphic (high-ruh-glif-ik)
Back: adj. difficult to understand, mysterious The students could not read the teacher's hieroglyphic writing on the board. Root: hieros (from Greek, meaning “sacred”); Root: glyph (from Greek gluphē, meaning “carving”); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives, meaning “pertaining to”)

Front: Define: homogenous (hoe-modj-ih-nus)
Back: adj. composed of similar or identical parts The audience was mostly a homogenous group of fashion design students, though one or two engineering students also attended. Prefix: homo- (from Greek, meaning “same”); Root: gen (from Greek genos, meaning “kind” or “race”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: hone (hone)
Back: v. to perfect v. to sharpen The swimmers spent all day in the water trying to hone their skills before the meet. Root: hone (from Old English hān, meaning “stone” or “rock”)

Front: Define: husband (huz-bund)
Back: v. to conserve The campers knew they would have to husband their supplies on their trip. Root: hus (from Old Norse hús, meaning “house”); Root: band (from Old Norse bóndi, meaning “occupier and tiller of the soil”)

Front: Define: nonplussed (non-plust)
Back: adj. confused She was nonplussed when her mother scolded her for no apparent reason. Prefix: non- (from Latin, meaning “not”); Root: plussed (from Latin plus, meaning “more”)

Front: Define: noxious (knock-shuss)
Back: adj. harmful in a physical or moral way Unfortunately, the group did not notice the noxious gas until it had claimed several victims. Root: nox (from Latin noxius, meaning “harmful”); Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives, meaning “characterized by”)

Front: Define: nuance (new-awnss)
Back: n. a small difference A trained scientist is sensitive to the nuances between these two seemingly identical procedures. Root: nuance (from Latin nubes, meaning “cloud”)

Front: Define: obdurate (ob-duh-ritt)
Back: adj. stubborn; inflexible and unyielding adj. emotionally cold; not compassionate Even when the witness began to cry, the accused remained obdurate and detached. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: dur (from Latin durus, meaning “hard”); Suffix: -ate (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: obsequious (ob-see-kwee-us)
Back: adj. very submissive and flattering In industries where obsequious service is expected, one generally leaves a tip. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “toward”); Root: sequ (from Latin sequi, meaning “to follow”); Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives, meaning “characterized by”)

Front: Define: obstinate (ob-stuh-nitt)
Back: adj. stubborn, unyielding to change an opinion The obstinate woman refused to move out of the other customers' way. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: stin (from Latin stare, meaning “to stand”); Suffix: -ate (forming adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: obviate (ob-vee-ehyt)
Back: v. to anticipate and prevent v. to make obsolete The Internet has all but obviated the need for radio stations. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: via (from Latin, meaning “way” or “road”); Suffix: -ate (forming verbs, meaning “to make”)

Front: Define: occlude (uh-clued)
Back: v. to close or block off v. to combine opposite surfaces The only way out of the cabin was occluded by a mound of fresh snow. Prefix: oc- (variant of ob-, from Latin, meaning “against”); Root: clude (from Latin claudere, meaning “to close”)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to see clearly Hint: starts with “d”
Back: discern synonyms: note, notice, focus, detect, perceive, distinguish She was able to discern the hidden meaning behind his words after careful reflection.

Front: Fill in the blank: The unexpected question ________ the speaker, causing him to lose his train of thought. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “embarrassed or disconcerted”.
Back: discomfited discomfit (diss-kum-fit) v. to unsettle v. to upset or prevent from succeeding

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. overdone or cliché Hint: starts with “h”
Back: hackneyed synonyms: tired, common, trite, stale, unoriginal The movie's plot was filled with hackneyed dialogue that felt tired and unoriginal.

Front: Fill in the blank: Attention to detail is the ________ of a great designer. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “a distinctive feature or trait”.
Back: hallmark hallmark (hall-mark) n. a unique, identifying trait n. a mark used to indicate the purity of certain metals

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to speak with intense emotions n. a rant Hint: starts with “h”
Back: harangue synonyms: diatribe, tirade, speech, lecture, oration The coach harangued his team after their lackluster performance. His harangue about politics lasted for nearly an hour.

Front: Fill in the blank: His lifestyle of constant parties and indulgence was a clear example of ________. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “pursuit of pleasure”.
Back: hedonism hedonism (heed-in-iz-um) n. dedication to pursuing pleasure

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to whip v. to make leather out of animal hide Hint: starts with “t”
Back: tan synonyms: flog, beat, treat, process, skin In old times, sailors were often tanned for disobedience. The workers tanned the hides to create durable leather goods.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ views on religion caused him to be ostracized by the community. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “holding beliefs contrary to accepted doctrine”.
Back: heretical heretical (huh-ret-ih-kull) adj. differing from official beliefs

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. difficult to understand, mysterious Hint: starts with “h”
Back: hieroglyphic synonyms: unclear, unreadable, cryptic, enigmatic, puzzling, obscure The professor's notes were so hieroglyphic that no one could make sense of them.

Front: Fill in the blank: The population of the small town was largely ________, with little cultural diversity. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “of the same kind”.
Back: homogenous homogenous (hoe-modj-ih-nus) adj. composed of similar or identical parts

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to perfect v. to sharpen Hint: starts with “h”
Back: hone synonyms: train, discipline; whet, grind, refine, enhance, improve She spent years honing her skills as a pianist to reach a professional level. He used a stone to hone the blade of his knife.

Front: Fill in the blank: They carefully ________ their resources to ensure they would last through the winter. Hint: Starts with “h” and means “to manage resources carefully”.
Back: husbanded husband (huz-bund) v. to conserve

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. confused Hint: starts with “n”
Back: nonplussed synonyms: perplexed, baffled, puzzled, bewildered, astonished, flabbergasted He was nonplussed by the strange behavior of his coworkers.

Front: Fill in the blank: The factory emitted ________ fumes that were dangerous to both the environment and the workers. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “harmful or poisonous”.
Back: noxious noxious (knock-shuss) adj. harmful in a physical or moral way

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a small difference Hint: starts with “n”
Back: nuance synonyms: degree, subtlety, shade, distinction, variation The actor's performance captured every nuance of the character's emotions.

Front: Fill in the blank: Despite their pleas, the judge remained ________ in his decision to impose the harshest penalty. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “stubbornly refusing to change”.
Back: obdurate obdurate (ob-duh-ritt) adj. emotionally cold; not compassionate

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. very submissive and flattering Hint: starts with “o”
Back: obsequious synonyms: flattering, sycophantic, servile, fawning, subservient His obsequious behavior towards his boss made him seem insincere and desperate for approval.

Front: Fill in the blank: Despite all the evidence, he remained ________ in his opinion. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “stubborn and inflexible”.
Back: obstinate obstinate (ob-stuh-nitt) adj. stubborn

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to anticipate and prevent v. to make obsolete Hint: starts with “o”
Back: obviate synonyms: anticipate, counteract; inhibit, stymie, prevent, eliminate, preclude The new safety measures were put in place to obviate potential accidents. The introduction of digital cameras quickly obviated the need for film.

Front: Fill in the blank: The dentist noticed that the patient's teeth did not ________ properly, causing discomfort. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “to block or close off”.
Back: occlude occlude (uh-clued) v. to close or block off v. to combine opposite surfaces
